Award.AwardTitle: The Infrared Radiative Impact of Antarctic Clouds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite their importance to radiative transfer, the amount of supercooled liquid water in polar clouds may be uncertain. This underestimation in turn results in significant radiation biases at the surface and TOA (top of the atmosphere) and misrepresentation of polar aerosol-cloud interactions. Recent work involving tuning a climate model to match mixed phase cloud distributions with observations resulted in an increase in net cloud radiative effects over Antarctica. A crucial component of understanding Antarctic climate, therefore, is a more accurate representation of the abundance of supercooled liquid in clouds and of corresponding cloud-radiative interactions.

Leveraging down-welling radiance measurement data previously collected with FT-IR instruments (Atmospheric Emitted Radiance Interferometers; AERIs) at South Pole Station - (2000) , Dome C - (2003) and to be made at McMurdo Station (planned for Nov. 2015-Nov. 2016) will be used to assess the seasonal dependence of cloud properties and cloud impacts on the local surface radiative budget. Two hypotheses will be considered:
1) The Antarctic radiation budget is highly sensitive to cloud properties, particularly thermodynamic phase.
2) The radiative impact of supercooled liquid in Antarctic clouds is significantly influenced by the temperature dependence of the complex refractive index of water (CRI)

POR.DRECONTENT:
Clouds cool our planet by reflecting sunlight out to space, and warm it through the greenhouse effect, by trapping infrared radiation. The role of clouds is particularly important in the Antarctic, where clouds can influence snowpack through precipitation or by causing warming and melting. At the same time, there are fewer measurements in the Antarctic compared to less remote locations. Thus, there is a need to improve our understanding of Antarctic clouds. Determining the warming or cooling of liquid clouds requires understanding how liquid droplets absorb and reflect light, quantified by the complex refractive index (CRI). Laboratory measurements have found that the CRI depends on temperature. This has important implications, since “supercooled” liquid clouds can exist down to temperatures close to -30 F. Despite this, the temperature dependence is typically ignored when cloud impacts are calculated, even though previous work has indicated this can result in significant errors.

The purpose of this project was to retrieve properties of clouds over two U.S. stations in Antarctica: South Pole and McMurdo, and to determine how the temperature dependence of the CRI influences their impact.  Broader impacts of this project include improved understanding of the role of Antarctic clouds in climate change, mentoring of undergraduate research students, and development of two educational modules: a module that allows students to run a simplified version of the cloud property retrieval code used in this work, and a module that uses the polar data used in this project as a real-world example for teaching topics in physical chemistry. 

This project was carried out successfully. Work done in this project improved techniques for characterizing polar clouds. In particular, techniques were improved for determining cloud height and other cloud properties from an instrument that looks at the cloud in the infrared (similarly to night vision goggles), from the surface. This is a useful complement to similar measurements made from satellite, which look at clouds from space, because viewing the cloud from the surface makes it easier to characterize the near-surface part of the cloud. It is also a useful complement to other methods for measuring cloud properties, like flying an airplane through the cloud or measuring light reflected off clouds by a laser (using an instrument called a lidar), which have different strengths and weaknesses.

These improved techniques were used to characterize clouds over South Pole and McMurdo, on the Antarctic coast. Cloud properties that were retrieved include cloud height, whether the cloud was composed of liquid droplets or ice crystals, the particle size, and the cloud “optical” thickness. This led to improvements in our understanding of clouds in Antarctica: it was found that clouds in Antarctica typically have significant amounts of liquid water that is below the freezing temperature, like clouds in the Arctic. However, liquid droplets in Antarctic clouds were found to be typically smaller. 

Dr. Rowe worked with a number of collaborators and mentored three undergraduate students, who helped meet project goals. One student helped develop educational materials, which have been taught in six ongoing undergraduate classes at different institutions and which have been made available online (https://serc.carleton.edu/penguin/modules/quantmech_spectra.html and https://github.com/prowe12/greyBodyRetrieval). A second undergraduate student helped quality-control the Antarctic measurements used in the cloud property retrievals, including weather balloon data and infrared spectra (a measure of the greenhouse effect). The third undergraduate student helped calculate and compile temperature-dependent CRI based on measurements and theoretical calculations; this product was used in this work and shared with the broader community, in order to improve calculations of the greenhouse effect of clouds. Dr. Rowe retrieved cloud properties at South Pole and McMurdo, and the undergraduate student helped calculate the effects of these clouds, and how the temperature dependence of the CRI influences it. 

 The work in this project was shared with the scientific community through numerous publications and presentations and was shared with the public through educational material as well as presentations at a middle school and participation in a public High School STEM fair. Computer code and data used in this work was shared through websites and online repositories, and is expected to help improve calculations of the effects of clouds in climate models and further research.
